text: All the earth shall worship thee, and shall sing unto thee; they shall sing to thy name. Selah.
text_kjv: All the earth shall worship thee, and shall sing unto thee; they shall sing to thy name. Selah.
text_niv: All the earth bows down to you;they sing praise to you,they sing praise to your name.” Selah
text_esv: All the earth worships you and sings praises to you; they sing praises to your name.” Selah
text_nlt: Everything on earth will worship you;they will sing your praises,shouting your name in glorious songs.” Interlude
text_msg: The whole earth falls to its knees—it worships you, sings to you,can't stop enjoying your name and fame.
text_nasb: 'All the earth will worship You, And will sing praises to You; They will sing praises to Your name.' Selah.
context: Psalm 66 is a hymn of praise and thanksgiving, likely composed for communal worship in the temple. The historical/cultural backdrop can be understood through the lens of Israel's experience with deliverance. While the exact historical event prompting its composition is debated, possibilities include a specific military victory, a successful harvest, or even a ritual celebration. The emphasis on 'all the earth' suggests a universalistic perspective, reflecting a growing awareness of Yahweh's sovereignty beyond Israel's borders. During the post-exilic period, such sentiments were particularly poignant, as Israel sought to rebuild and re-establish its identity within a larger, often hostile, world. Temple worship, with its elaborate rituals and music, served as a focal point for national unity and spiritual renewal. The use of musical instruments and singing played a crucial role in expressing devotion and remembering God's mighty acts. Selah, interspersed throughout the Psalms, is likely a musical notation, possibly indicating a pause for instrumental interlude, a change in vocal dynamic, or a moment of reflection. Understanding the cultural context of communal worship, the importance of music, and the broader theme of God's universal dominion helps us to appreciate the depth of feeling expressed in verse 4. It reminds us that even amidst the challenges of their own history, the psalmists looked forward to a time when all nations would acknowledge Yahweh as Lord.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 66:4 presents a powerful vision of God's ultimate reign and the universal scope of his worship. 'All the earth shall worship thee' speaks to the future culmination of God's redemptive plan, where every nation and every people will acknowledge his sovereignty. This is not simply a passive acknowledgement, but an active declaration of allegiance and devotion. The repetition of 'shall sing unto thee; they shall sing to thy name' underscores the importance of joyful expression in worship. Singing, as an act of praise, becomes a testament to God's character and his saving works. 'To sing to thy name' implies a deep understanding and appreciation of God's revealed character. 'Name' in Hebrew theology represents the totality of God's being, his attributes, and his reputation. Therefore, singing to his name is more than just uttering words; it's engaging with the very essence of God in worship. The phrase 'Selah' adds a layer of significance, inviting the worshiper to pause and meditate on the preceding words. It’s a call for deeper reflection on the implications of universal worship and the profound joy of praising God's holy name. The verse connects to broader biblical themes of God's covenant with humanity, his promise of redemption for all nations (Genesis 12:3), and the vision of a future kingdom where God's will is done on earth as it is in heaven (Matthew 6:10). It reinforces the idea that God is not just the God of Israel, but the God of all creation, deserving of universal adoration.
application: The practical application of Psalm 66:4 for modern believers is multifaceted. Firstly, it challenges us to cultivate a global perspective in our faith. We are called to look beyond our immediate surroundings and recognize God's work in all nations. This involves supporting missions, praying for global evangelism, and engaging with people from diverse cultural backgrounds. Secondly, it emphasizes the importance of joyful and expressive worship. Our worship should not be a mere formality, but a genuine outpouring of gratitude and love for God. This could involve incorporating music, art, and other forms of creative expression into our worship services and personal devotions. Thirdly, it reminds us to reflect on the meaning of God's name and to deepen our understanding of his character. This requires consistent study of scripture, prayer, and meditation on God's attributes. The call to universal worship also challenges us to examine our own prejudices and biases. If we truly believe that all the earth will one day worship God, then we must treat all people with dignity and respect, regardless of their background or beliefs. We can actively fight against injustice and oppression, working towards a world where all people have the opportunity to know and worship God freely. Moreover, we should actively invite others to join in the chorus of praise, sharing the good news of the gospel and demonstrating God's love in tangible ways. By embracing a global perspective, cultivating joyful worship, and reflecting on God's character, we can live out the vision of Psalm 66:4 in our daily lives.
prayer: Sovereign God, creator of all the earth, we bow before you in humble adoration. Your glory extends beyond the confines of our understanding, reaching to the farthest corners of creation. We long for the day when every knee shall bow and every tongue confess that you are Lord. Teach us to worship you with sincerity and joy, to sing praises that reflect the depth of our love and gratitude. Open our eyes to see your hand at work among all nations, and empower us to be instruments of your peace and reconciliation. Help us to break down the barriers that divide us and to embrace all people as your beloved children. May our lives be a testament to your boundless love and grace. Grant us the wisdom to understand your character more fully, and the courage to share your good news with the world. Selah. Amen.

faqs.answer: The phrase 'all the earth' reflects a broader theological understanding of God's sovereignty extending beyond Israel. It foreshadows the universal scope of God's redemptive plan as seen in the New Testament, encompassing all nations and peoples.
faqs.question: Why does the verse mention 'all the earth' instead of just Israel?

faqs.answer: Singing 'to thy name' signifies more than just vocalizing words; it means praising and glorifying God's revealed character, attributes, and reputation. It is an intimate and deeply personal expression of worship.
